explanation:
1) strcmp — The target function uses strcmp to compare the request method against constant strings. To determine whether the code violates the MISRA rule you must inspect the actual implementation or mapping of strcmp in this build (it might be a library or a project-supplied wrapper) to see if it internally calls memcmp when comparing NUL-terminated strings.  
2) memcmp — The MISRA rule specifically forbids using memcmp to compare NUL-terminated strings. If strcmp (or any wrapper used here) invokes memcmp, that constitutes a violation. You must inspect memcmp (or its implementation/alias) to confirm whether it is used for these comparisons.  
3) MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET — This macro/constant is one operand of strcmp. You need its definition to confirm it is (or is not) a NUL-terminated string literal or some other representation; if it is NUL-terminated, comparing it with strcmp is the exact situation covered by the MISRA rule when memcmp is used.  
4) MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD — Same reason as MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET: verify it is a NUL-terminated string constant (so the comparison is a NUL-terminated string comparison) and to check for any unusual definition that might change the analysis (e.g., not a plain C string).
